name: 美國文學
description: This course is a one-semester introduction to the history of American literature, surveying material from the discovery period through the mid-nineteenth century. The course takes a chronological approach to the literary material, with discussion of the historical circumstances and social and intellectual trends in each period. We will cover a variety of genres: history, sermon, political pamphlet, lyric, short story and novel.
goals: To survey American literature from the discovery period through the mid-nineteenth century
To cover a variety of genres: history, sermon, political pamphlet, lyric, short story and novel
syllabus:
Course Description

In this course we study—mostly chronologically—the major writers andtheir writings in different periods of American literature. Through the readingand discussion of individual texts, we will build connections and understandthe differences between authors, styles, and thematic concerns. Our goal is becomefamiliar with the development of American literature, understand its pluralisticnature, and engage with related themes, issues, and problems. In this currentsemester, our readings cover up to the end of the nineteenth century. Thoseinterested in pursuing American literature further are encouraged to take theelective course on the twentieth-century American literature.

Text: The Norton Anthology of AmericanLiterature. Shorter Seventh Edition. Ed. Nina Baym. New York: Norton, 2008.(available at Bookman \[書林書局\], 23687226)

**Tentative Schedule**

**Early American Literature**

Week 1

Orientation: An Introduction to American Literature

Film Viewing: _1492_ (1992)

Week 2

Columbus (25-28); De Vaca (29-36); Smith, from _The General History of Virginia, New England, and the Summer Isles_ (45-54);

Week 3

The Iroquois Creation Story (17-21); “The Pima Creation Story” (21-24)

American Literature 1680-1820

Week 4

Bradford (57-75); Winthrop (75-87); Taylor (Prologue; Meditation 8); Edwards (selected passages from “Sinners in the Hands of an Angry God” 194 ff)

Week 5

Franklin, “The Way to Wealth” (220-226); Crèvecoeur, selected passages from _Letters from an American Farmer_ (310 ff); Paine, selected passages from _Common Sense_ (326 ff); Freneau, “The Wild Honey Suckle”; “On the Religion of Nature” (416-417; 418-419)

Week 6

Equiano, from _The Interesting Narrative of the Life of Olaudah Equiano_” (357ff); Bradstreet, from _Contemplations_ (98ff); Wheatley, “On Being Brought from Africa to America” and “To the University of Cambridge, in New England” (420-421)

**American Literature 1820-1865**      

Week 7

Irving , “Rip Van Winkle” (455-466); Emerson, _Nature_ (492-519)

Week 8

Emerson, “Self-Reliance” (532-550); Bryant, “To a Waterfowl” (477-479); Thoreau, “Resistance to Civil Government” (829-844); from _Walden_ (844ff; read any part you like)

Week 9

Midterm

Week 10

Film Viewing: _The Scarlet Letter_

Week 11

Hawthorne, selected passages from _The Scarlet Letter_ (handouts); “Young Goodman Brown” (605-614)

Week 12

Dickinson, poems 67; 185; 328; 435; 465; 712; 754; etc; Poe, “Annabel Lee” (678-679); “The Raven” (675-678), from “The Philosophy of Composition” (724 ff)

Week 13

Walt Whitman, “Preface to _Leaves of Grass_” (996-1010), selected lines from _Crossing Brooklyn Ferry_ and _Song of Myself_

Week 14

Melville, “Bartleby, the Scrivener” (1093-1118); Stowe, from _Uncle Tom’s Cabin_ (767 ff)

**American Literature 1865-1914**      

Week 15

Film viewing: _Adventures of Huckleberry Finn_

Week 16

Mark Twain, _Adventures of Huckleberry Finn_ (1265 ff.; especially Chapters I, V, VIII, XIII, XIV, XXVIII, XXXI, XXXV, and Chapter the Last )

Week 17

Review

Week 18

Final Exam (Format TBA)
